speaker: alex
text: Welcome back to Claude Code Mastery. I'm Alex, and today we're getting into the really powerful stuff: actually modifying your code with Claude's help.

speaker: jamie
text: I'm Jamie, and this is the episode I've been waiting for. Reading and navigating code is great, but the real productivity gains come from Claude helping me write and edit code, right?

speaker: alex
text: Absolutely. By the end of this episode, you'll understand the three main tools Claude uses to modify files: Read, Edit, and Write. You'll know when to use each one and how to review changes safely.

speaker: jamie
text: We touched on the Read tool last episode, but let's go deeper. What exactly happens when Claude reads a file?
chapter: SEGMENT 1: THE READ TOOL IN DEPTH (5 minutes)

speaker: alex
text: When Claude uses the Read tool, it requests the contents of a specific file at a specific path. The tool returns the file content with line numbers, which is crucial for making precise edits later.
chapter: SEGMENT 1: THE READ TOOL IN DEPTH (5 minutes)

speaker: jamie
text: Why are line numbers important?
chapter: SEGMENT 1: THE READ TOOL IN DEPTH (5 minutes)

speaker: alex
text: Because when Claude wants to edit a file, it needs to reference exact locations. If Claude reads a file and sees the function you want to change is on lines 45 through 60, it can target its edit precisely.
chapter: SEGMENT 1: THE READ TOOL IN DEPTH (5 minutes)

speaker: jamie
text: Makes sense. Does Claude always read the entire file?
chapter: SEGMENT 1: THE READ TOOL IN DEPTH (5 minutes)

speaker: alex
text: Not necessarily. The Read tool accepts optional parameters for offset and limit. So Claude can read lines 100 through 200 of a large file, or just the first 50 lines. This keeps context manageable.
chapter: SEGMENT 1: THE READ TOOL IN DEPTH (5 minutes)

speaker: jamie
text: What about really large files?
chapter: SEGMENT 1: THE READ TOOL IN DEPTH (5 minutes)

speaker: alex
text: For very large files, Claude often reads strategically. It might first search for a function name to find its line number, then read just that section. Or it might read the first 100 lines to understand the file structure, then jump to specific sections.
chapter: SEGMENT 1: THE READ TOOL IN DEPTH (5 minutes)

speaker: jamie
text: That's pretty clever. It's like how I would navigate a large file manually.
chapter: SEGMENT 1: THE READ TOOL IN DEPTH (5 minutes)

speaker: alex
text: Exactly. Claude mimics the patterns experienced developers use. Skim for structure, then dive into details where needed.
chapter: SEGMENT 1: THE READ TOOL IN DEPTH (5 minutes)

speaker: jamie
text: Okay, let's talk about actually changing code. How does the Edit tool work?

speaker: alex
text: The Edit tool is Claude's primary way to modify existing files. It works on a find-and-replace principle. Claude specifies an old string that exists in the file and a new string to replace it with.

speaker: jamie
text: So it's like find and replace in my text editor?

speaker: alex
text: Similar, but more targeted. Claude has to provide a string that uniquely identifies the location in the file. If the old string appears multiple times, the edit will fail unless Claude explicitly says to replace all occurrences.

speaker: jamie
text: Why that constraint?

speaker: alex
text: Safety. Imagine Claude wants to change a variable name from "data" to "userData." If it just replaced every "data" in the file, it might accidentally change strings like "database" or "metadata" or comments. The uniqueness requirement prevents that.

speaker: jamie
text: So Claude has to include enough context to be unique?

speaker: alex
text: Right. Instead of just "data," Claude might specify "const data = fetchUser" as the old string, which is much more likely to be unique in the file.

speaker: jamie
text: Can you walk through what an edit looks like in practice?
chapter: SEGMENT 3: WATCHING AN EDIT IN ACTION (5 minutes)

speaker: alex
text: Sure. Let's say you ask Claude to add error handling to a function. First, Claude reads the file to see the current code. It might see a function like: async function fetchUser id, then return await api dot get user id.
chapter: SEGMENT 3: WATCHING AN EDIT IN ACTION (5 minutes)

speaker: jamie
text: A simple fetch without any error handling.
chapter: SEGMENT 3: WATCHING AN EDIT IN ACTION (5 minutes)

speaker: alex
text: Right. Claude then proposes an edit. The old string would be that entire function body. The new string would be the same code wrapped in a try-catch block with appropriate error handling.
chapter: SEGMENT 3: WATCHING AN EDIT IN ACTION (5 minutes)

speaker: jamie
text: And I see this proposal before it happens?
chapter: SEGMENT 3: WATCHING AN EDIT IN ACTION (5 minutes)

speaker: alex
text: Yes! Claude shows you exactly what the old code is, what the new code will be, and asks for permission. You can approve it, reject it, or ask for modifications before it runs.
chapter: SEGMENT 3: WATCHING AN EDIT IN ACTION (5 minutes)

speaker: jamie
text: That visibility is reassuring. I can catch mistakes before they happen.
chapter: SEGMENT 3: WATCHING AN EDIT IN ACTION (5 minutes)

speaker: alex
text: That's the whole point. Claude is powerful, but you stay in control. Review every change, especially when you're first learning the workflow.
chapter: SEGMENT 3: WATCHING AN EDIT IN ACTION (5 minutes)

speaker: jamie
text: What about creating entirely new files? Is that different?

speaker: alex
text: Yes, that's the Write tool. While Edit modifies existing files, Write creates new files or completely overwrites existing ones.

speaker: jamie
text: When would Claude use Write versus Edit?

speaker: alex
text: Write is for new files: a new component, a new test file, a new utility module. It's also used when you want to completely replace a file's contents rather than make a surgical change.

speaker: jamie
text: What's the permission flow for Write?

speaker: alex
text: Similar to Edit. Claude shows you the file path it wants to write to and the content it will write. You approve or deny. If the file already exists, you'll be warned that it will be overwritten.

speaker: jamie
text: Good. I wouldn't want to accidentally clobber an existing file.

speaker: alex
text: Right. In practice, Claude tries to use Edit for existing files because it's less destructive. Write is reserved for new files or complete rewrites.

speaker: jamie
text: How do I know which one Claude will use?
chapter: SEGMENT 5: EDIT VS WRITE: MAKING THE RIGHT CHOICE (4 minutes)

speaker: alex
text: Claude makes this decision automatically based on the situation. If you ask to "add a function to utils.js," Claude will use Edit because it's adding to an existing file. If you ask to "create a new helper file," Claude will use Write.
chapter: SEGMENT 5: EDIT VS WRITE: MAKING THE RIGHT CHOICE (4 minutes)

speaker: jamie
text: What if I want to replace a whole file?
chapter: SEGMENT 5: EDIT VS WRITE: MAKING THE RIGHT CHOICE (4 minutes)

speaker: alex
text: You can ask explicitly. "Rewrite the config file completely" or "replace the entire contents of setup.js" signals to Claude that a full Write is appropriate.
chapter: SEGMENT 5: EDIT VS WRITE: MAKING THE RIGHT CHOICE (4 minutes)

speaker: jamie
text: Are there cases where Edit is better even for big changes?
chapter: SEGMENT 5: EDIT VS WRITE: MAKING THE RIGHT CHOICE (4 minutes)

speaker: alex
text: Generally, smaller, targeted edits are safer. Even if you're changing a lot, multiple Edit operations let you review each change individually. A single Write that replaces everything is harder to review.
chapter: SEGMENT 5: EDIT VS WRITE: MAKING THE RIGHT CHOICE (4 minutes)

speaker: jamie
text: Incremental changes are easier to verify.
chapter: SEGMENT 5: EDIT VS WRITE: MAKING THE RIGHT CHOICE (4 minutes)

speaker: alex
text: Exactly. I usually prefer Claude to make a series of edits rather than one big rewrite. It's easier to catch issues and rollback if needed.
chapter: SEGMENT 5: EDIT VS WRITE: MAKING THE RIGHT CHOICE (4 minutes)

speaker: jamie
text: What about changes that span multiple files? Like adding a feature that touches the model, controller, and view?
chapter: SEGMENT 6: HANDLING MULTIPLE FILE EDITS (5 minutes)

speaker: alex
text: Claude handles multi-file changes by making edits sequentially. It will edit the first file, then the second, then the third. Each edit gets its own permission prompt.
chapter: SEGMENT 6: HANDLING MULTIPLE FILE EDITS (5 minutes)

speaker: jamie
text: Can I approve them all at once?
chapter: SEGMENT 6: HANDLING MULTIPLE FILE EDITS (5 minutes)

speaker: alex
text: If you trust the pattern, you can tell Claude to proceed with all related changes. But especially for complex features, reviewing each file change individually is wise.
chapter: SEGMENT 6: HANDLING MULTIPLE FILE EDITS (5 minutes)

speaker: jamie
text: What if one edit fails?
chapter: SEGMENT 6: HANDLING MULTIPLE FILE EDITS (5 minutes)

speaker: alex
text: Claude will tell you about the failure and typically try to recover or ask for guidance. Maybe the file changed since it was read, or the string it was trying to match doesn't exist anymore.
chapter: SEGMENT 6: HANDLING MULTIPLE FILE EDITS (5 minutes)

speaker: jamie
text: So I might need to help Claude get back on track?
chapter: SEGMENT 6: HANDLING MULTIPLE FILE EDITS (5 minutes)

speaker: alex
text: Sometimes. You might say "read the file again" or "the function was renamed, look for newFunctionName instead." It's a collaboration.
chapter: SEGMENT 6: HANDLING MULTIPLE FILE EDITS (5 minutes)

speaker: jamie
text: What's the best way to review Claude's proposed changes?

speaker: alex
text: First, look at the scope. Is Claude changing what you expected? If you asked to fix a typo and Claude is rewriting the whole function, that's a red flag.

speaker: jamie
text: Scope creep in AI suggestions.

speaker: alex
text: Exactly. Second, read the actual diff. Does the new code make sense? Are there obvious bugs or issues? Trust your developer instincts here.

speaker: jamie
text: What if I'm not sure about a change?

speaker: alex
text: Ask Claude to explain it! "Why did you change this part?" or "What does this new code do?" Claude will walk you through its reasoning. Sometimes the explanation reveals issues you hadn't noticed.

speaker: jamie
text: Or confirms that it's the right approach.

speaker: alex
text: Right. And don't hesitate to say "no, try a different approach." Claude can suggest alternatives. The first proposal isn't always the best one.

speaker: jamie
text: What are some common editing patterns you use with Claude?

speaker: alex
text: One of my favorites is "add X to Y." Add logging to this function. Add validation to this endpoint. Add error handling to this API call. It's specific about what and where.

speaker: jamie
text: Clear instructions produce clear results.

speaker: alex
text: Another pattern is "change X from A to B." Change the timeout from 30 seconds to 60 seconds. Change the color scheme from blue to green. Very explicit about the transformation.

speaker: jamie
text: What about refactoring?

speaker: alex
text: For refactoring, I often say "extract this logic into a separate function" or "move this code into its own file." Claude understands these refactoring concepts and can execute them cleanly.

speaker: jamie
text: Does Claude handle renaming well?

speaker: alex
text: Yes! "Rename the function from handleClick to handleButtonClick everywhere" is a great prompt. Claude will use Grep to find all usages and update them consistently.

speaker: jamie
text: Does Claude handle different file types differently?
chapter: SEGMENT 9: WORKING WITH DIFFERENT FILE TYPES (5 minutes)

speaker: alex
text: Claude understands many file types and their conventions. JavaScript, TypeScript, Python, Go, Rust, Java, and many more. It knows the syntax and common patterns for each.
chapter: SEGMENT 9: WORKING WITH DIFFERENT FILE TYPES (5 minutes)

speaker: jamie
text: What about non-code files like JSON or YAML?
chapter: SEGMENT 9: WORKING WITH DIFFERENT FILE TYPES (5 minutes)

speaker: alex
text: Claude handles configuration files really well. "Update the package.json to add a new dependency" or "change the database port in docker-compose.yml" are natural requests.
chapter: SEGMENT 9: WORKING WITH DIFFERENT FILE TYPES (5 minutes)

speaker: jamie
text: What about markdown or documentation?
chapter: SEGMENT 9: WORKING WITH DIFFERENT FILE TYPES (5 minutes)

speaker: alex
text: Absolutely. "Add a section to the README about installation" or "update the API docs with the new endpoint" work great. Claude treats documentation as a first-class editing target.
chapter: SEGMENT 9: WORKING WITH DIFFERENT FILE TYPES (5 minutes)

speaker: jamie
text: Does it handle Jupyter notebooks?
chapter: SEGMENT 9: WORKING WITH DIFFERENT FILE TYPES (5 minutes)

speaker: alex
text: Yes! Claude has specific support for notebook files. It can read cells, understand the flow of a notebook, and edit individual cells. There's even a specialized NotebookEdit tool for this.
chapter: SEGMENT 9: WORKING WITH DIFFERENT FILE TYPES (5 minutes)

speaker: jamie
text: What if Claude makes a change I don't like? How do I undo it?

speaker: alex
text: The best safety net is git. If you're working in a git repository, you can always revert changes. Before any major editing session, I recommend committing your current state so you have a clean rollback point.

speaker: jamie
text: Git is the ultimate undo.

speaker: alex
text: Exactly. You can use git diff to see what changed, git checkout to discard changes to specific files, or git reset to go back to your last commit.

speaker: jamie
text: Can Claude help with the rollback?

speaker: alex
text: Yes! You can say "undo the last changes to auth.js" and Claude will help you revert. Or "show me what changed" and Claude will run git diff for you.

speaker: jamie
text: That's handy. The same tool that made the changes can unmake them.

speaker: alex
text: And honestly, mistakes are part of learning. Don't be afraid to experiment knowing you can always roll back.

speaker: jamie
text: What are your top tips for getting the best editing results?
chapter: SEGMENT 11: TIPS FOR EFFECTIVE EDITING (4 minutes)

speaker: alex
text: First, read before you edit. Make sure Claude has actually read the file before asking for changes. Say "read the login function in auth.js" before "add rate limiting to the login function."
chapter: SEGMENT 11: TIPS FOR EFFECTIVE EDITING (4 minutes)

speaker: jamie
text: Context before action.
chapter: SEGMENT 11: TIPS FOR EFFECTIVE EDITING (4 minutes)

speaker: alex
text: Second, be specific about what you want to preserve. "Add validation but keep the existing error messages" tells Claude what not to change.
chapter: SEGMENT 11: TIPS FOR EFFECTIVE EDITING (4 minutes)

speaker: jamie
text: Constraints help.
chapter: SEGMENT 11: TIPS FOR EFFECTIVE EDITING (4 minutes)

speaker: alex
text: Third, work incrementally. Instead of "refactor this entire module," try "refactor the first function in this module" then "now the second one." Smaller chunks are easier to review.
chapter: SEGMENT 11: TIPS FOR EFFECTIVE EDITING (4 minutes)

speaker: jamie
text: Baby steps are safer steps.
chapter: SEGMENT 11: TIPS FOR EFFECTIVE EDITING (4 minutes)

speaker: alex
text: And fourth, use your editor alongside Claude. Keep the file open in your IDE. When Claude makes a change, you'll see it update. You can also make manual tweaks and tell Claude about them.
chapter: SEGMENT 11: TIPS FOR EFFECTIVE EDITING (4 minutes)

speaker: jamie
text: What mistakes do new users commonly make with editing?

speaker: alex
text: The biggest one is asking for changes without Claude having read the file. If Claude hasn't seen the current code, it's guessing about what needs to change.

speaker: jamie
text: Always read first.

speaker: alex
text: Another pitfall is vague requests. "Make this better" doesn't give Claude much to work with. Better is "improve the error messages to be more user-friendly" or "optimize this loop for performance."

speaker: jamie
text: Specificity again.

speaker: alex
text: Also, some users approve changes too quickly without reading them. I know it's tempting to just click approve, but those few seconds of review can catch significant issues.

speaker: jamie
text: Trust but verify.

speaker: alex
text: Exactly. And finally, not using version control. If you're making significant changes, commit frequently. It's your safety net.

speaker: jamie
text: Can we give listeners an exercise to practice editing?

speaker: alex
text: Here's a good one. Pick a function in your codebase that doesn't have comments. Ask Claude to read the function, then ask it to add a documentation comment explaining what the function does.

speaker: jamie
text: A safe, low-risk edit.

speaker: alex
text: Right. Review the comment Claude proposes. Does it accurately describe the function? Is the style consistent with your project? Approve it and check the result.

speaker: jamie
text: And we've practiced the full edit cycle.

speaker: alex
text: Exactly. Read, request change, review, approve. That's the pattern you'll use for all edits.

speaker: jamie
text: Great episode. I feel ready to start making edits with confidence. What's coming up?

speaker: alex
text: Episode four dives into search and exploration in depth. We'll cover advanced patterns for Grep and Glob, using the specialized Explore agent for complex searches, and techniques for understanding unfamiliar codebases.

speaker: jamie
text: From editing what we know to discovering what we don't know.

speaker: alex
text: Exactly. See you in episode four!

speaker: jamie
text: Happy editing, everyone!
